channel.title: Simple Shield
channel.description:
Still practicing my modelling skills and getting used to blender. Hoping to figure out texturing in blender soon.
[IMG]http://i1060.photobucket.com/albums/t459/moore_zyle/Models/shield.png[/img] [IMG]http://i1060.photobucket.com/albums/t459/moore_zyle/Models/wireframe.png[/img]

item.title: Simple Shield
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Soon you will look around and start seeing how you can model stuff.

Personally I hardly use values for something unless I cant just select it and scale uniformly. Not like using fixed values is bad, I’m just lazy and like eyeballing it.

Protip: start memorizing shortkeys to increase modeling speed tenfold.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Shield
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:7, topic:432485”][quote author=man_killerx link=topic=535196.msg3912879#msg3912879 date=1328918373]

Yeah, I’m new to modelling. I used to make some crazy things in Cheetah3D when I had a Mac (mostly cubes subdivided to look like flower petals, etc). I’m trying to better myself making quality, low-poly models (like 317 models). I’ve seen a lot of people new to modelling shove cylinders into each other, and try to pass it off as good work. I’m more concerned with learning proper modelling techniques.

Hope you’re not talking about me.
[/quote]
:’) sorry but I lol’d.

@OP Are you using a tutorial(s) to learn? Or are you just teaching yourself as you go along and maybe google for a tutorial for something more complicated (like realism rendering or texturing)? Could never get used to blender’s UI. Tried the new one (2.5?) and I just didn’t like it all that much either. Granted, it was a huge improvement from 2.49 or w/e. I love 3ds max, but sadly I can’t torrent it unless I want to wait a week.[/quote]

I’m not really using any tutorials, just basic manipulation (mostly with the mouse, but defined values for tuning).

I start with quick-sketching in my notebook, usually do 3-4 revisions for the main concepts, and then 1-2 for fine-tuning designs.

Read full topic

Yeah, I’m new to modelling. I used to make some crazy things in Cheetah3D when I had a Mac (mostly cubes subdivided to look like flower petals, etc). I’m trying to better myself making quality, low-poly models (like 317 models). I’ve seen a lot of people new to modelling shove cylinders into each other, and try to pass it off as good work. I’m more concerned with learning proper modelling techniques.
[/quote]
Hope you’re not talking about me.[/quote]

Not you specifically, but there have been many people passing through here that either trace and triangulate, or create primitives because that’s what they were suggested.
